Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Annual Meeting of the West Coast Bacterial Physiologists; Asilomar Conference Center in Pacific Grove, California-December 12-14, 2014

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award, funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program, will help to offset registration costs for 75 graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to attend the West Coast Bacterial Physiologists Meeting. At this meeting, approximately 90% of the talks will be presented by undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows. Junior Faculty initiating their research programs will be invited in order to facilitate their integration into the broader scientific community. The scientific focus of the meeting, foundational aspects of microbial physiology, will be relevant to biotechnological applications (bioremediation, biofuels), metabolomics and other systems-level -omics approaches, genome to phenome studies, and synthetic biology.

The West Coast Bacterial Physiologists Meeting will be held in December of 2014 at the Asilomar Conference Center in Pacific Grove, California. The meeting will be organized into four scientific sessions over a three-day period. Each of the four sessions will begin with an invited "John Ingraham Lecturers in Microbial Physiology" which will span the range of microbial physiology fields and include new and emerging topics. The meeting program and abstracts will be made publicly available on the meeting website. The meeting will give young researchers the opportunity to give an oral presentation at a scientific conference, and will help to integrate junior Faculty into the research community, which will create new collaborative research opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Annual Meeting of the West Coast Bacterial Physiologists (WCBP) provides a forum for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to present and discuss the results of their ongoing research projects. The WCBP meeting also encourages attendance and active participation of advanced undergraduates, especially those interested in attending graduate school. As all presentations are in the form of talks, the meeting provides an excellent opportunity for graduate, undergraduate and postdoctoral students to gain experience in effective scientific presentation in a supportive yet scientifically rigorous environment. The support provided by NSF was targeted specifically to subsidize the costs of the meeting for graduate, undergraduate and postdoctoral students in an effort to allow their continuing attendance, and potentially increase the numbers of students able to attend. In fact we had a 30% increase in postdoctoral attendees at the 2014 meeting compared to recent years, which we attribute to the reduced cost of the meeting that was possible due to this NSF grant.

 

The 2014 Annual Meeting of the West Coast Bacterial Physiologists was held on December 12-14 at the Asilomar Conference Center in Pacific Grove, CA. There were 107 attendees, including 28 postdoctoral fellows, 38 graduate students, 6 undergraduate students and 24 principal investigators. The meeting consisted of four formal and three informal sessions with a broad focus on basic and biomedical bacterial physiology, genetics and genomics. Four invited individuals presented John Ingraham overview lectures: Carol Gross, University of California, San Francisco, ‘New Insights into Protein Synthesis and Folding by Studying Responses to Temperature Stress’; Rob Knight, University of Colorado, Boulder, ‘Tracking the Human Microbiome from Birth to Death (and beyond)’; Jennifer Pett-Ridge, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, ‘Imaging Complex Metabolic Community Interactions as Revealed by nano-SIMS’; John Roth, University of California, Davis, ‘How Selection Alone Mimics Mutagenesis: The Tyranny of the Obvious’. Each gave a 40 min presentation to lead off the four formal sessions.

 

There were 27 submitted presentations of 15 min each in the formal sessions. Over fifty percent of these presentations were from postdoctoral fellows and 25% were from graduate students. Two undergraduates also presented a research talk. The submitted presentations covered a wide range of relevant topics, including genomic and microbial community analyses, microbial phylogeny, transcriptional regulation, chemotaxis, motility, microbial communication, microbial development, plant-microbe symbioses, microbial biochemistry, and archaeal virology. The program and abstracts from this and previous WCBP meetings can be accessed at http://wcbacterialphysiologists.ucdavis.edu/.

 

The meeting makes a significant impact on the next generation of scientific leaders in microbial biology, as it enabled them to present their research and engage with leaders in microbial physiology in in-depth discussions. The meeting provided not only presentation experience to the trainees, but also feedback on their presentation skills and research findings, and also allowed them to make valuable contacts in the field of microbial physiology that may serve them in the future, including identifying new areas of research and possible post-graduate, postdoctoral, and other career opportunities.
